class="align-center">0.4</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">CA-EDT</td><td class="align-center">0.8</td><td class="align-center">0.6</td><td class="align-center">0.9</td><td class="align-center">0.6</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="rowsep-1 align-left">CA-OxA</td><td class="rowsep-1 align-center">0.7</td><td class="rowsep-1 align-center">0.6</td><td class="rowsep-1 align-center">0.6</td><td class="rowsep-1 align-center">0.2</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">C1400</td><td class="align-center">0.3</td><td class="align-center">0.2</td><td class="align-center">0.5</td><td class="align-center">–</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">C-MPA</td><td class="align-center">0.6</td><td class="align-center">0.4</td><td class="align-center">0.5</td><td class="align-center">0.5</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">C-EDT</td><td class="align-center">0.6</td><td class="align-center">0.3</td><td class="align-center">0.5</td><td class="align-center">0.4</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">C-OxA</td><td class="align-center">0.4</td><td class="align-center">0.2</td><td class="align-center">0.6</td><td class="align-center">0.2</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0130"><span><a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about TEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TEM</a> and SEM imaging shows that surface treatments have no visible impact on the topology of the carbon surface (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a>). SEM-EDX semi quantitative analysis (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S1</span></span></a><span>) shows that all C1400 samples pretreated with sulfuric acid show at least 0.5 %wt. S content attributed to the presence of sulfates (further confirmed in the <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS analysis</a>, </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>c). Moreover, C-MPA and C-EDT samples have around 0.5 %wt. S content attributed to the presence of MPA and EDT molecules. No sulfur is detected for C1400 or C-OxA. No significant differences in ligand loading are observed in the presence of sulfuric acid. Despite several washings, K and Si from lignocellulose precursors are still detected in the analysis [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib40" name="bbib40" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib40"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">40</span></span></a>].</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig2"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324006827-gr2.jpg" height="719" alt="Fig. 2" aria-describedby="cap0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324006827-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324006827-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0015"><p id="fspara0015"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. XPS peak fitting of (a) C 1s spectra of CA-L materials, (b) C 1s spectra of C1400 and C-L materials, and (c) S 2p spectra of CA, CA-MPA, CA-EDT, CA-OxA, C-MPA, and C-EDT.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0135"><span><a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS</a> analyses have been performed to corroborate the incorporation of the ligand molecules onto the carbon surface. Elemental quantification is summarized in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl2" name="btbl2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 2</span></span></a>. C <em>1s</em>, O <em>1s</em> and S <em>2p</em> are the main narrow spectra that have been studied for this purpose.</div><div class="tables frame-topbot colsep-0 rowsep-0" id="tbl2"><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0045"><p id="tspara0015"><span class="label">Table 2</span>. XPS quantification of C1400 and surface-treated samples.</p></span></span><div class="groups"><table><thead><tr class="rowsep-1 valign-top"><th scope="col">Material</th><th scope="col" class="align-center">C (%at.)</th><th scope="col" class="align-center">O (%at.)</th><th scope="col" class="align-center">S (%at.)</th><th scope="col" class="align-center">K (%at.)</th><th scope="col" class="align-center">Si (%at.)</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">CA</td><td class="align-center">90.5</td><td class="align-center">7.6</td><td class="align-center">1.0</td><td class="align-center">0.3</td><td class="align-center">0.5</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">CA-MPA</td><td class="align-center">87.7</td><td class="align-center">9.1</td><td class="align-center">2.8</td><td class="align-center">0.2</td><td class="align-center">0.2</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">CA-EDT</td><td class="align-center">85.7</td><td class="align-center">8.3</td><td class="align-center">4.8</td><td class="align-center">1.1</td><td class="align-center">0.2</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="rowsep-1 align-left">CA-OxA</td><td class="rowsep-1 align-center">86.0</td><td class="rowsep-1 align-center">9.8</td><td class="rowsep-1 align-center">2.0</td><td class="rowsep-1 align-center">1.8</td><td class="rowsep-1 align-center">0.3</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">C1400</td><td class="align-center">88.7</td><td class="align-center">7.4</td><td class="align-center">0.0</td><td class="align-center">3.7</td><td class="align-center">0.2</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">C-MPA</td><td class="align-center">90.8</td><td class="align-center">6.1</td><td class="align-center">2.1</td><td class="align-center">0.6</td><td class="align-center">0.3</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">C-EDT</td><td class="align-center">88.4</td><td class="align-center">5.5</td><td class="align-center">3.4</td><td class="align-center">2.0</td><td class="align-center">0.7</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">C-OxA</td><td class="align-center">92.8</td><td class="align-center">5.3</td><td class="align-center">0.0</td><td class="align-center">1.6</td><td class="align-center">0.3</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0140">The C <em>1s</em> peak fitting (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a and b) shows the same three components for all the materials, corresponding to C–C/C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond">C, C–O/C–S and C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond"><span>O from lower to higher binding energy (BE). For molecules with <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/carboxylic-acid" title="Learn more about carboxylic acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carboxylic acid</a> groups (CA-MPA, CA-OxA, C-MPA, and C-OxA) an additional peak at around 289&nbsp;eV, assigned to the presence of –COOH, has been observed. This signal is not detectable in the other samples. The peak fitting of O </span><em>1s</em> spectra follows the same tendency (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a>).</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145">All materials show C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond">O, C–OH/C–O–C signals and CA-MPA, CA-OxA, C-MPA, and C-OxA have an additional component at higher BE assigned to –COOH [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib50" name="bbib50" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib50"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib51" name="bbib51" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib51"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">51</span></span></a>]. Both, C <em>1s</em> and O <em>1s</em>, confirm the successful incorporation of OxA and MPA on the carbon surface. Besides, S <em>2p</em> narrow spectra were studied to confirm the presence of sulfur species in MPA and EDT samples (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>c). The presence of sulfates has been detected in all samples, with a comparatively higher concentration observed in samples pretreated with sulfuric acid. Moreover, C-MPA, CA-MPA, C-EDT, and CA-EDT display a characteristic <em>2p</em><sub><em>3/2</em></sub> signal at approximately 163.3&nbsp;eV, which can be attributed to the presence of C–S–C bonds [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib52" name="bbib52" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib52"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">52</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib53" name="bbib53" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib53"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">53</span></span></a><span>] thereby verifying the bonding between carbon and molecule thiol groups. Oppositely, as expected, C1400, CA, C-OxA, and CA-OxA do not exhibit such signals. In both cases, CA-L and C-L covalent bonding between carbon and molecule is detected regardless of the incorporation of sulfuric acid in the functionalization. These findings are consistent with the conclusions drawn from the <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/thermogravimetric-analysis" title="Learn more about TGA from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TGA</a> curves.</span></div></section><section id="sec3.2"><h3 id="sectitle0075" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2. Electrochemical characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0150">CA-L, C-L and pristine C1400 were used to fabricate electrodes for their testing in half-cell Na-ion batteries. Initially, CA-L samples were subjected to galvanostatic cycling at C/10, during 100 cycles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl3" name="btbl3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 3</span></span></a>). A slight increase in capacity is observed for the surface-treated samples, with an 8&nbsp;% capacity improvement for CA-MPA in the 100th cycle and a 6&nbsp;% for CA-EDT and CA-OxA. It is noteworthy that the CA sample (C1400 pretreated only with sulfuric acid) shows a 2&nbsp;% capacity improvement, which makes it very similar to C1400; however, it degrades faster than the other samples. Comparing the capacity in the 2nd cycle and 100th cycle, CA shows capacity retention of 84&nbsp;%, lower than the 91&nbsp;% observed for C1400 and CA-OxA, and 87&nbsp;% for CA-EDT and CA-MPA. Additionally, all samples exhibit Coulombic efficiencies values close to 100&nbsp;% during the 100 cycles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5</span></span></a>). Furthermore, surface-treated samples show improved iCE than C1400, that indicates the decrease of charge required for the formation of the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl3" name="btbl3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 3</span></span></a>). Additionally, to get a better insight into the effects of the ligands, samples without acid, C-L, were cycled under the same conditions at C/10 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d). C-MPA and C-EDT are the best treatments exhibiting 12&nbsp;% and 6&nbsp;% capacity improvement at 100th cycle respectively in comparison to pristine C1400. C-OxA shows a worse performance and stability. In terms of capacity, there are no differences between C-MPA, C-EDT and their acid counterparts but C-MPA and C-EDT show slightly better stability (93&nbsp;% and 89&nbsp;% capacity retention from the 2nd up to 100th cycle) (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl3" name="btbl3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 3</span></span></a>). Furthermore, iCE is increased for the three treatments and Coulombic efficiencies are stable and close to 100&nbsp;% during the 100 cycles of C-MPA and C-EDT (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5</span></span></a><span>). In summary, most surface treatments have a positive effect on the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> of C1400. Notably, MPA and EDT exhibit better performance, regardless of the presence or absence of acid. Additionally, the stability of the materials is enhanced.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig3"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324006827-gr3.jpg" height="435" alt="Fig. 3" aria-describedby="cap0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324006827-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (906KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (906KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324006827-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0020"><p id="fspara0020"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. Galvanostatic cycling at C/10 (a) Capacity vs. cycle number of CA-L samples, (d) Capacity vs. cycle number of C-L samples. Capacity axis have been adjusted to better visualize the capacity and stability effects during cycling. Charge-discharge curve in the first cycle of (b) CA-L and (e) C-L samples. Differential Capacity vs. Voltage first cycle magnification in the 0.5–1.5&nbsp;V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup> region of (c) CA-L and (f) C-L samples.</p></span></span></figure><div class="tables frame-topbot colsep-0 rowsep-0" id="tbl3"><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0050"><p id="tspara0020"><span class="label">Table 3</span>. Summary of the electrochemistry features of C1400 and surface treated materials cycled at C/10.</p></span></span><div class="groups"><table><thead><tr class="rowsep-1 valign-top"><th scope="col"><em>Material</em></th><th scope="col" class="align-center">100<em>th</em> <em>cycle (mAh·g<sup>−1</sup>)</em></th><th scope="col" class="align-center"><em>Capacity retention (%)</em><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl3fna" name="btbl3fna" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl3fna"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><em><sup>a</sup></em></span></span></a></th><th scope="col" class="align-center"><em>Capacity improvement (%)</em><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl3fnb" name="btbl3fnb" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl3fnb"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><em><sup>b</sup></em></span></span></a></th><th scope="col" class="align-center"><em>iCE (%)</em></th><th scope="col" class="align-center"><em>1st</em> <em>peak (V)</em></th><th scope="col" class="align-center"><em>2nd peak (V)</em></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">CA</td><td class="align-center">223</td><td class="align-center">84</td><td class="align-center">2</td><td class="align-center">71</td><td class="align-center">1.11</td><td class="align-center">0.67</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">CA-MPA</td><td class="align-center">235</td><td class="align-center">87</td><td class="align-center">8</td><td class="align-center">73</td><td class="align-center">1.14</td><td class="align-center">0.73</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">CA-EDT</td><td class="align-center">229</td><td class="align-center">87</td><td class="align-center">6</td><td class="align-center">71</td><td class="align-center">1.11</td><td class="align-center">0.73</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="rowsep-1 align-left">CA-OxA</td><td class="rowsep-1 align-center">231</td><td class="rowsep-1 align-center">91</td><td class="rowsep-1 align-center">6</td><td class="rowsep-1 align-center">74</td><td class="rowsep-1 align-center">1.15</td><td class="rowsep-1 align-center">0.66</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">C1400</td><td class="align-center">217</td><td class="align-center">91</td><td class="align-center">–</td><td class="align-center">70</td><td class="align-center">1.13</td><td class="align-center">0.63</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">C-MPA</td><td class="align-center">243</td><td class="align-center">93</td><td class="align-center">12</td><td class="align-center">72</td><td class="align-center">1.11</td><td class="align-center">0.70</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">C-EDT</td><td class="align-center">230</td><td class="align-center">89</td><td class="align-center">6</td><td class="align-center">75</td><td class="align-center">1.14</td><td class="align-center">0.70</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">C-OxA</td><td class="align-center">205</td><td class="align-center">91</td><td class="align-center">–</td><td class="align-center">73</td><td class="align-center">1.11</td><td class="align-center">0.60</td></tr></tbody></table></div><dl class="footnotes"><dt id="tbl3fna">a</dt><dd><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="ntpara0010">Calculated from the 100th relative to the 2nd cycle.</div></dd><dt id="tbl3fnb">b</dt><dd><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="ntpara0015">Calculated from the 100th cycle and compared to the C1400.</div></dd></dl></div></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0155">Additionally, galvanostatic cycling at 1C was also performed to identify the influence of the treatments at higher C-rates (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6</span></span></a>) where hard carbons might show more limitations. The C1400 reference sample exhibits a decline in capacity after 55 cycles, most likely due to FEC consumption, whereas the surface-treated samples demonstrate enhanced stability, improved capacity and a delayed FEC consumption. Among them, C-L appears to be the most promising materials, with a notable emphasis on C-MPA and C-EDT with capacity improvements in the 100th cycle up to 13&nbsp;% for C-MPA and 18&nbsp;% for C-EDT and a capacity retention of 93&nbsp;% for C-MPA and 95&nbsp;% for C-EDT vs. 83&nbsp;% for C1400 at higher C-rates (calculated from cycle 6 to 100).</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0160"><span>Capacity, stability, and iCE enhancements are hypothesized to stem from differences in SEI formation and composition. This process is contingent upon the interactions between the surface groups of the <a href="/topics/chemistry/carbon-material" title="Learn more about carbon material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon material</a> and the electrolyte. The first Na charge–discharge curve is useful to see different SEI formation and to calculate iCE (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>b for CA-L and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>e for C-L samples). These curves represent the first discharge (sodiation)–charge (desodiation) cycle at C/10, between 2&nbsp;V and 0&nbsp;V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup>. A typical curve shows a sloping region (attributed to the adsorption of Na<sup>+</sup> ions onto defects of the material) from high potentials up to 0.1&nbsp;V and a plateau region below 0.1&nbsp;V, attributed to the intercalation of Na<sup>+</sup> ions between carbon layers and pore filling by Na atoms. It is observed that in all samples the capacity improvement comes from both the slopping (above 0.1&nbsp;V) and plateau (below 0.1&nbsp;V) regions. To gain further insight, a detailed analysis of the inverse derivatives ((dV/dx)<sup>−1</sup>) of this 1st cycle was conducted (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>c for CA-L samples and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>f for C-L samples). Two peaks can be distinguished corresponding to the SEI formation reactions [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib54" name="bbib54" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib54"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">54</span></span></a>]. In all samples, the first peak appears in discharge at around 1.1&nbsp;V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup> and it is attributed to the decomposition of the FEC additive. To confirm this, the first cycle was performed in the same conditions without additive in electrolyte by using the C1400 sample (1&nbsp;M NaPF<sub>6</sub> in EC:DMC). As can be seen in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a>, the peak at 1.1&nbsp;V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup> is not visible. Significant disparities are not observed in the initial peak among any of the samples, as it primarily depends on the presence of the FEC additive.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0165">Hence, the main focus is put on the second peak, which emerges between 0.6&nbsp;V and 0.7&nbsp;V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup>. This peak is associated with EC and DMC decomposition and the formation of –CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2-</sup> species (polycarbonates, alkyl carbonates and Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib20" name="bbib20" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib20"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib55" name="bbib55" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib55"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">55</span></span></a>]. Depending on the treatment applied, the peak appears at different voltage suggesting differences in the decomposition process (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl3" name="btbl3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 3</span></span></a>) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib56" name="bbib56" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib56"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">56</span></span></a>]. More precisely, the peak in CA-MPA and CA-EDT samples is less prominent and shifted to a higher voltage (0.73&nbsp;V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup>) which might suggest that Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> and polycarbonate formation are less favorable (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib56" name="bbib56" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib56"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">56</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib57" name="bbib57" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib57"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">57</span></span></a>]. On the other hand, CA and CA-OxA show lower voltage values (0.66&nbsp;V and 0.67&nbsp;V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup>). We speculate that –CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2-</sup> formation could be enhanced by the presence of carboxylic groups, as discussed later in <em>ex-situ</em> XPS studies. Finally, two great peaks in the 0V–0.1&nbsp;V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup> region are found in the discharge and charge processes, attributed to sodium insertion and de-insertion, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S8</span></span></a>). Non-acid pretreated samples (C-L, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>f) were examined, and similar correlations were identified. In C-MPA and C-EDT, the peak associated with solvent decomposition appears at higher voltages (0.7&nbsp;V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup>), whereas C-OxA exhibited the peak at 0.6&nbsp;V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup>, thus substantiating the previously drawn conclusions.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig4"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324006827-gr4.jpg" height="577" alt="Fig. 4" aria-describedby="cap0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324006827-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (828KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (828KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324006827-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0025"><p id="fspara0025"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. Na-ion apparent diffusion coefficients calculated from the corresponding C1400 and C-L GITT profiles for (a) discharge and (b) charge with magnified views of the plateau region.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0170">Once the electrodes are stabilized, it is possible to differentiate between adsorption, intercalation and pore filing. The 100th charge–discharge curve and adsorption/insertion/pore filling column graphs were compared to clarify which step is most significantly influenced by surface treatments (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9</span></span></a>). At both C-rates (C/10 and 1C) surface treatments seem to enhance both sodium insertion and adsorption. This effect is particularly noticeable in MPA and EDT treatments, especially at the higher rate of 1C, where HCs encounter more challenges.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0175">In summary, adding sulfuric acid to the surface treatment does not seem to provide any benefit regarding the amount of ligand loaded. Furthermore, the electrochemical results closely resemble those of the non-acid counterparts. Consequently, the primary focus of subsequent studies has been directed towards the C-L samples.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0180">To gain deeper insights into the underlying processes and the impact of each ligand on the electrochemical processes, N<sub>2</sub><span> adsorption and <a href="/topics/chemistry/titration" title="Learn more about GITT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">GITT</a> measurements were conducted on C-L samples. Tuning the size or blocking the micropores entrance is a common strategy to avoid the undesired entry of solvated sodium ions into the pores [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib58" name="bbib58" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib58"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">58</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib59" name="bbib59" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib59"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">59</span></span></a><span>]. If solvated ions enter the micropores, they can get trapped because of their large size. Therefore, blocking the pores reduces this loss. Moreover, the increase in the external surface area forces sodium storage through intercalation in the carbon matrix. Alternatively, if the micropore size is reduced, the sodium ions are forced to enter the pores without solvent molecules. Non-solvated ions enter and leave pores more easily leading to reversible storage of <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about Na ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Na ions</a> and improved iCE [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib25" name="bbib25" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib25"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">25</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib26" name="bbib26" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib26"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib60" name="bbib60" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib60"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">60</span></span></a>]. Our results suggest that short-chain ligands can partially block the material micropores increasing the carbon external surface area (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S2</span></span></a>). These data align with the improvement in the intercalation and the decrease in pore filling contribution, indicating a consistent trend in the observed results. GITT measurements (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a>) were performed at C/10 with C1400 and C-L samples (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span>) to calculate the apparent sodium <a href="/topics/chemistry/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficients from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficients</a> (D) of the materials using the following formula:</span><span class="display"><span id="ufd1" class="formula"><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-2-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;>(</mo><mfrac is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>m</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>B</mi></msub><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>V</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>M</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>M</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo stretchy=&quot;true&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>(</mo><mfrac is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x394;</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>E</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>S</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x394;</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>E</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>t</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac><mo stretchy=&quot;true&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>)</mo></mrow><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msup></mrow></math>" transform="translate(60,509)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(621,-107)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-42"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1071,0)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-56"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(412,-107)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4D"></use></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(303,-403)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(686,-107)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-42"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1136,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-53"></use></g></g></g></g><use xlink:href="#MJSZ2-29" is="true" x="3038" y="-1"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3635,877)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(7383,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJSZ2-28" is="true"></use><g is="true" transform="translate(597,0)"><g transform="translate(120,0)"><rect stroke="none" width="1625" height="60" x="0" y="220"></rect><g is="true" transform="translate(60,524)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-394"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(589,0)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-45"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(522,-110)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-53"></use></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(131,-411)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-394"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(589,0)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-45"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(522,-107)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-74"></use></g></g></g></g></g><use xlink:href="#MJSZ2-29" is="true" x="2462" y="-1"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3060,877)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mn is="true">4</mn><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">π</mi><mi is="true">τ</mi></mrow></mfrac><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">m</mi><mi is="true">B</mi></msub><msub is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi><mi is="true">M</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">M</mi><mi is="true">B</mi></msub><mi is="true">S</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">S</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">t</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-2"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mn is="true">4</mn><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">π</mi><mi is="true">τ</mi></mrow></mfrac><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">m</mi><mi is="true">B</mi></msub><msub is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi><mi is="true">M</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">M</mi><mi is="true">B</mi></msub><mi is="true">S</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">S</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">t</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>where <em>V</em><sub><em>M</em></sub><span> is the <a href="/topics/materials-science/density-specific-gravity" title="Learn more about molar volume from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">molar volume</a> and </span><em>M</em><sub><em>B</em></sub><span> is the <a href="/topics/chemistry/molar-mass" title="Learn more about molar mass from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">molar mass</a>; both can be substituted by the inverse of the material density (1.973&nbsp;g&nbsp;cm</span><sup>−3</sup> for C1400 [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib40" name="bbib40" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib40"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">40</span></span></a>], and 0.096&nbsp;g&nbsp;cm<sup>−3</sup> for Vulcan, according to producer data). Same density values were used for their respective surface treated materials. <em>τ</em> is the relaxation time, <em>m</em><sub><em>B</em></sub> is the active mass in the electrode and <em>S</em> is the electrode area. <em>ΔE</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> corresponds to the steady-state voltage change and <em>ΔE</em><sub><em>t</em></sub><span> to the transient voltage change. The main assumptions are that the <a href="/topics/chemistry/electrode-material" title="Learn more about electrode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode material</a><span> is homogeneous, the <a href="/topics/chemistry/molar-volume" title="Learn more about molar volume from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">molar volume</a> change of the active material during charge or discharge is not large enough and the current should be a low value with a short duration time.</span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0185">All samples exhibit similar D values which remain mostly constant during the sloping region. At 0.1&nbsp;V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup>, an abrupt decrease is observed due to the different mechanism of sodiation at the beginning of the plateau region. Afterward, D sharply increases displaying the typical U-shape of hard carbons to later decrease again near the cut-off voltage. C-OxA and especially C-MPA and C-EDT show a less pronounced decrease at 0.1&nbsp;V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup> than C1400, which indicates that these materials would be less susceptible to polarization and display a better rate capability [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib61" name="bbib61" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib61"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">61</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib62" name="bbib62" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib62"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">62</span></span></a>]. Indeed, C-L samples show better performance at 1C cycling than the untreated carbon (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6b</span></span></a>). Moreover, D values of C-MPA and C-EDT in the plateau region (below 0.1&nbsp;V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup>) and near to the cut-off voltage are higher than C1400 and C-OxA ones. This indicates a faster diffusion of sodium during intercalation in the carbon matrix in C-MPA and C-EDT [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib61" name="bbib61" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib61"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">61</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib62" name="bbib62" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib62"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">62</span></span></a>]. Furthermore, D values for desodiation cycle (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>b), exhibit similar tendencies. C-MPA and C-EDT have slightly higher D values in the intercalation region and a smoother transition into the adsorption mechanism at 0.12&nbsp;V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0190">Galvanostatic cycling tests at different C-rates for C-L samples was performed (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11</span></span></a><span>). C-MPA and C-EDT demonstrate enhanced performance as compared to C1400 and C-OxA, with C-EDT showing slightly superior performance at higher C-rates. To better understand the involved processes, <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a> (EIS) measurements were conducted (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S12</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Note S1</span></span></a>). C-MPA and C-EDT exhibit significantly lower resistivity (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S3</span></span></a>) in the SEI region (85.6Ω and 58.5Ω) than C1400 and C-OxA (182.7Ω and 265.7Ω), indicating a more favorable Na<sup>+</sup> ion diffusion through the SEI. Moreover, these results point at a superior stability and electrochemical performance after the 40 cycles at different C-rates.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0195">Based on these results, it is clear that carbons treated with molecules containing –SH groups exhibit better performance, faster sodium diffusion in the plateau region, and improved micropore blockage [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib58" name="bbib58" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib58"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">58</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib59" name="bbib59" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib59"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">59</span></span></a>]. It is probable that the presence of –COOH groups favors CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2−</sup> formation while –SH groups might lead to a more favorable SEI composition that directly affects capacity, stability, and iCE. For this reason, and to confirm the hypothesis, <em>ex-situ</em> XPS characterization of the electrodes has been conducted to identify and understand the SEI composition differences and their relationship with the functional groups of the organic ligands.</div></section><section id="sec3.3"><h3 id="sectitle0080" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.3. Understanding SEI composition – <em>Ex-situ</em> XPS</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0200"><em>Ex-situ</em> XPS analysis after the first discharge–charge cycle enables the determination and quantification of the primary components and species of the SEI formed on the surface of the carbon electrode. In order to monitor NaF, –CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2-</sup>, Na<sub>2</sub>O and organic species formation, special emphasis has been placed on C <em>1s</em>, O 1s and F <em>1s</em> narrow spectra. All analyzed samples have been discharged (sodiated)–charged (desodiated) at C/10 to ensure an adequate formation of the SEI and make them comparable. The discussion focuses on C-L surface-treated samples, but similar results are observed for CA-L samples (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S13</span></span></a>). As compared to non-cycled materials (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>), in the C <em>1s</em> narrow spectra (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a) two additional components at 283&nbsp;eV and around 290&nbsp;eV have been detected. The first one at 283&nbsp;eV corresponds to sodium intercalated into the hard carbon Na<sub>x</sub>-HC [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib33" name="bbib33" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib33"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">33</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib63" name="bbib63" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib63"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">63</span></span></a>]. This signal has been experimentally confirmed in literature through argon etching of the SEI [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib33" name="bbib33" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib33"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">33</span></span></a>], and can be used as an indicator of SEI thickness [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib63" name="bbib63" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib63"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">63</span></span></a>]. Considering that the maximum XPS penetration depth is approx. 10&nbsp;nm, a more prominent Na<sub>x</sub>-HC signal in XPS could be correlated with a thinner SEI [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib64" name="bbib64" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib64"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">64</span></span></a>]. It has been reported that a thinner SEI can improve Na<sup>+</sup> ion transport [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib65" name="bbib65" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib65"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">65</span></span></a>]. The second signal at 290&nbsp;eV corresponds to –CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2-</sup><span>, attributed to the formation of <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/polycarbonate" title="Learn more about polycarbonates from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polycarbonates</a> and Na</span><sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> in the SEI [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib53" name="bbib53" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib53"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">53</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib63" name="bbib63" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib63"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">63</span></span></a>]. Furthermore, <em>ex-situ</em> O <em>1s</em> peak fitting reveals several differences compared to the analyses conducted before cycling. The –COOH signal (534–535&nbsp;eV) is not clearly detected; however, two additional components emerge, one at lower energy bindings (531&nbsp;eV) attributed to Na<sub>2</sub>O, and another at higher energy bindings (536&nbsp;eV), representing the Na Auger signal (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>b). Besides, F <em>1s ex-situ</em> XPS fitting after the first discharge–charge display two components corresponding to the NaPF<sub>6</sub> electrolyte (687&nbsp;eV) and the NaF (684&nbsp;eV) formed in the SEI (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>c) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib35" name="bbib35" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib35"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">35</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib53" name="bbib53" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib53"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">53</span></span></a>]. For the following <em>ex-situ</em> XPS discussion, all the percentages correspond to atomic percentages and as commented, the focus will be on C <em>1s</em> peak fitting (–CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2-</sup> and Na<sub>x</sub>-HC components), F <em>1s</em> (NaF component) and O <em>1s</em> (Na<sub>2</sub>O). Results are summarized in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl4" name="btbl4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 4</span></span></a> and element composition is compiled in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S4</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig5"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324006827-gr5.jpg" height="492" alt="Fig. 5" aria-describedby="cap0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324006827-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324006827-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0030"><p id="fspara0030"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. XPS fitting of (a) C 1s, (b) O 1s, and (c) F 1s <em>ex-situ</em> spectra of samples C1400, C-MPA, C-EDT and C-OxA after one charge–discharge cycle at C/10.</p></span></span></figure><div class="tables frame-topbot colsep-0 rowsep-0" id="tbl4"><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0055"><p id="tspara0025"><span class="label">Table 4</span>. SEI composition summary from <em>ex-situ</em> XPS analysis after the first cycle at C/10 for C1400 and C-L samples. Discharge capacities correspond to the 100th cycle of the galvanostatic cycling at C/10.</p></span></span><div class="groups"><table><thead><tr class="rowsep-1 valign-top"><th scope="col" rowspan="2"><br><em>Material</em></th><th scope="col" class="align-center" colspan="2">C 1s</th><th scope="col" class="align-center">O 1s</th><th scope="col" class="align-center">F 1s</th><th scope="col" class="align-center" rowspan="2"><em>Dis. Cap. (mAh·g<sup>−1</sup>)</em></th></tr><tr class="rowsep-1 valign-top"><th scope="col" class="align-center"><em>Na</em><sub><em>x</em></sub><em>-HC (%at.)</em></th><th scope="col" class="align-center">–CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2-</sup><em>(%at.)</em></th><th scope="col" class="align-center"><em>Na</em><sub><em>2</em></sub><em>O (%at.)</em></th><th scope="col" class="align-center"><em>NaF (%at.)</em></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">C1400</td><td class="align-center">3.1</td><td class="align-center">16.0</td><td class="align-center">13.2</td><td class="align-center">24.6</td><td class="align-center">217</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">C-MPA</td><td class="align-center">5.8</td><td class="align-center">12.8</td><td class="align-center">20.0</td><td class="align-center">42.0</td><td class="align-center">243</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">C-EDT</td><td class="align-center">6.4</td><td class="align-center">11.5</td><td class="align-center">16.9</td><td class="align-center">45.3</td><td class="align-center">230</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">C-OxA</td><td class="align-center">4.3</td><td class="align-center">13.7</td><td class="align-center">11.9</td><td class="align-center">33.9</td><td class="align-center">205</td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0205">Starting with C <em>1s</em>, C1400 SEI has higher –CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2-</sup><span> content (16.0 %at.) than other samples. C-MPA and C-EDT, which have shown the most positive <a href="/topics/chemistry/electrochemistry" title="Learn more about electrochemistry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemistry</a> results, seem to have a thinner SEI (5.8 %at. and 6.4 %at. Na</span><sub>x</sub>-HC, respectively) with reduced amounts of –CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2-</sup><span> (12.8 %at. and 11.5 %at., correspondingly). On the other hand, C-OxA has similar values to C1400 and exhibits the worst performance. The correlation between the chemical SEI composition and the electrochemical behavior is evident. The presence of short-chain ligands and appropriate functional groups on the carbon surface promotes the formation of a thinner SEI and prevents unnecessary electrolyte decomposition (i.e., showing higher iCE values). This is clearly evidenced in the 1C <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemistry" title="Learn more about electrochemistry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemistry</a> of C-L and CA-L materials, where the sudden capacity fading attributed to FEC consumption, is notably delayed (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6</span></span></a>). EDT and MPA treatments (both containing –SH groups) display a higher Na<sub>x</sub>-HC content, which has been reported to be associated with a thinner SEI, and have lower –CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2-</sup><span> content, which can result in higher <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/ion-current" title="Learn more about ionic conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic conductivity</a>. On the other hand, the treatment with ligands containing only –COOH groups (C-OxA samples) promotes the formation of –CO</span><sub>3</sub><sup>2-</sup> which can hinder the performance.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0210">O <em>1s</em><span> detailed spectra have been studied to gain insight into the <a href="/topics/chemistry/inorganic-compound" title="Learn more about inorganic compound from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">inorganic compound</a> Na</span><sub>2</sub>O (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>b). Peak fitting of C-MPA and C-EDT spectra demonstrate higher quantities of Na<sub>2</sub>O (20.0 %at. and 16.9 %at., respectively) than C1400 (13.2 %at.) which can result in better stability and improved Na<sup>+</sup> conductivity. C-OxA components are very similar to C1400 results with lower amount of Na<sub>2</sub>O (11.9 %at.) which explains its hindered performance. These results align with the previous C <em>1s</em> conclusions.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0215">Furthermore, F <em>1s</em> narrow spectra were analyzed (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><span>c). In this context, the NaF component stands out as particularly intriguing, given that a NaF-rich SEI has demonstrated advantageous effects such as better Na diffusion. Carbons treated with ligands: C-MPA (42.0 %at.), C-EDT (45.3 %at.) and C-OxA (33.9 %at.) show an increased amount of NaF content than C1400 (24.6 %at.) which can justify the enhanced <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/electrochemistry" title="Learn more about electrochemistry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemistry</a> of the C-L samples.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0220">In particular, carbons treated with thiol-containing molecules (MPA and EDT) show the highest content of Na<sub>2</sub>O and NaF in their SEI, related to better cycling, Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion, and capacity retention. It is likely that the presence of thiol groups can promote the coordination of Na<sup>+</sup> on the surface of the electrode leading to an enrichment in sodium species (Na<sub>2</sub>O and NaF) during the SEI formation. These results are consistent with the GCD, N<sub>2</sub> adsorption, GITT, and C <em>1s ex-situ</em> XPS conclusions.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0225">As commented, C <em>1s,</em> F <em>1s</em> and O <em>1s</em> spectra of samples treated in the presence of acid (CA-L) have also been analyzed and the conclusions are similar, with CA-MPA and CA-EDT showing the best results (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S13</span></span></a> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S5</span></span></a>).</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0230">C-MPA and C-EDT treatments exhibited the highest specific capacities with excellent retention after 100 cycles (93&nbsp;% and 89&nbsp;%), blocked micropores, higher Na&nbsp;<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;diffusion in the plateau region and a thinner SEI with increased amounts of Na<sub>2</sub>O, NaF and lower amounts of –CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2-</sup><span>. It can be concluded that thiol-containing ligands without acid are the most beneficial surface treatments for the carbon anode in <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about SIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SIBs</a>.</span></div></section><section id="sec3.4"><h3 id="sectitle0085" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.4. Ligand treatments to soft carbon</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0235">In light of the positive results observed with hard carbon treated with MPA and EDT, we decided exploring whether this surface treatment could enhance the performance of other carbon types used in commercial SIBs, such as soft carbons. For this reason, Vulcan XC-72R carbon black was treated with these molecules (V-MPA and V-EDT) and tested as anodes in SIBs half-cells. ATR-FTIR analysis of Vulcan, V-MPA, and V-EDT (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S14</span></span></a>) shows similar trends than observed for hard carbon (HC). The V-MPA spectrum shows a new signal at 1680&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup>, attributed to the C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond"><span>O vibration of the MPA carboxylic group. <a href="/topics/materials-science/thermogravimetric-analysis" title="Learn more about TGA from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TGA</a> analysis confirms the successful loading of MPA and EDT. Their curves show important mass losses within the range of chemical bonding (150 °C–400&nbsp;°C) when compared to pristine Vulcan (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S15</span></span></a>). The total amount of ligands is 1&nbsp;%wt. for both samples. The higher surface area of Vulcan allows for a slightly higher loading of organic molecules than C1400. Capacity improvements have been observed for both treatments during 100 cycles at C/10. As compared to pristine Vulcan XC-72R (136&nbsp;mAh·g<sup>−1</sup> at 100th cycle), V-MPA shows an 18&nbsp;% capacity improvement (161&nbsp;mAh·g<sup>−1</sup>) and V-EDT a 16&nbsp;% increase (158&nbsp;mAh·g<sup>−1</sup>) (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>a). At a higher current, 1C, greater improvements are observed at the 100th cycle for both V-MPA and V-EDT. V-MPA showed a 23&nbsp;% capacity improvement (155&nbsp;mAh·g<sup>−1</sup>) and V-EDT 31&nbsp;% (165&nbsp;mAh·g<sup>−1</sup>) in comparison to Vulcan (126&nbsp;mAh·g<sup>−1</sup>) (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>b).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig6"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324006827-gr6.jpg" height="228" alt="Fig. 6" aria-describedby="cap0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324006827-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (348KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (348KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324006827-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0035"><p id="fspara0035"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. Galvanostatic cycling capacity vs. cycle number at of Vulcan, V-MPA and V-EDT at (a) C/10 and (b) 1C.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0240">Additionally, N<sub>2</sub> adsorption shows a similar tendency where micropores are partially blocked with MPA while the external surface is promoted resulting in better and reversible insertion/deinsertion of sodium (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S6</span></span></a><span>). Apparent <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficients from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficients</a> of Vulcan and V-MPA were also calculated at C/10 (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S16</span></span></a>). The shape is consistent with a sloping region attributed to the adsorption of sodium on the surface, and the absence of U-shape, compatible with the reduced intercalation observed in soft carbons [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib66" name="bbib66" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib66"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">66</span></span></a>]. During the whole discharge (sodiation) process, V-MPA shows higher diffusion values, while they are similar for both materials (V-MPA and Vulcan) during charge (desodiation).</div></section></section><section id="sec4"><h2 id="sectitle0090" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0245"><span>Surface treatments using various short-chain organic ligands (MPA, EDT OxA), both with and without acid, have been applied to hard carbon material and has been tested as anode in SIBs. The treatments have been beneficial for the <a href="/topics/chemistry/electrode-material" title="Learn more about electrode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode material</a><span> showing excellent stability after 100 cycles and an improvement in capacity up to 12&nbsp;% at C/10 and 18&nbsp;% at 1C. Additionally, iCE is increased to 14&nbsp;% in the best cases in comparison to the pristine material. Treatments with ligands incorporating <a href="/topics/chemistry/thiol-group" title="Learn more about thiol groups from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">thiol groups</a> (C-MPA and C-EDT) have proven to be the most advantageous. The reasons behind these improvements have been studied using </span></span><em>ex-situ</em> XPS, N<sub>2</sub> adsorption, and GITT. Best performing materials show a thinner SEI with lower –CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2-</sup> amount and higher NaF and Na<sub>2</sub>O content related to better Na diffusion, as confirmed by GITT measurements in the plateau region. N<sub>2</sub> adsorption measurements have shown micropore blocking and an increase of external surface area which seems to favor sodium insertion and extraction.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0250">Moreover, MPA and EDT treatments have also been applied to soft carbon Vulcan XC-72R and tested as the anode in SIBs half-cells. Capacity enhancement has been observed especially at higher charge–discharge rates (1C) showing more than a 30&nbsp;% capacity improvement with great stability after 100 cycles. Again, micropore blocking and increased Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion seem to be responsible for this enhancement.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0255">In summary, we have shown that a simple, fast, low temperature treatment with short-chain organic ligands can improve the performance of carbon materials used as anodes in SIBs. Moreover, these treated-carbons show good performance at fast charge–discharge rates, which could be especially relevant for certain applications such as electric mobility.</div></section><section id="sec5"><h2 id="sectitle0095" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0260"><strong>Sergio Aina:</strong> Writing – original draft, Investigation, Formal analysis, Data curation. <strong>Blaz Tratnik:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Investigation, Data curation. <strong>Alen Vizintin:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision, Investigation, Data curation. <strong>Elena Tchernychova:</strong> Investigation, Data curation. <strong>M. Pilar Lobera:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision. <strong>Robert Dominko:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision, Funding acquisition. <strong>María Bernechea:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision, Project administration, Funding acquisition, Conceptualization.</div></section></div><section id="coi0010"><h2 id="sectitle0100" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0265">The authors declare the following financial interests/personal relationships which may be considered as potential competing interests:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0270">Maria Bernechea reports financial support was provided by MCIN, AEI. Maria Bernechea reports financial support was provided by CIBER-BBN. Maria Bernechea reports financial support was provided by ICTS NANBIOSIS. If there are other authors, they declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ack0010"><h2 id="sectitle0105" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0275">Authors acknowledge ERA.NET network for funding NOEL project, SA, MPL and MB acknowledge <span id="gs7">MCIN/AEI/10.13039/501100011033</span> (Ref: <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">PRTR-C17.I1</span></span></a> with funding from <span id="gs1">European Union NextGenerationEU</span>, promoted by the <span id="gs2">Government of Aragon</span>, and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">PCI2019–10363</span></span></a>), <span id="gs8">CIBER-BBN</span>, <span id="gs9">ICTS ‘‘NANBIOSIS’’</span>, instrumentation and technical advice provided by the National Facility <span id="gs3">ICTS ELECMI node “Laboratorio de Microscopias Avanzadas”</span>, and <span id="gs4">Servicio General de Apoyo a la Investigación-SAI, Universidad de Zaragoza</span>. class="text-content u-font-serif"><section id="da0010"><h2 id="sectitle0025" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Data availability</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030">Data will be made available on request.</div></section></div><div class="Tail"></div><div><section class="bibliography u-font-serif text-s" id="cebib0010"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top class="reference" id="sref2"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">J.M. Tarascon, M. Armand</div><div id="ref-id-sref2" class="title text-m">Issues and challenges facing rechargeable lithium batteries</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Nature, 414 (2001), pp. 359-367, <a class="anchor pdf link anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon"
