class=\"key-dates-help\"><h3 class=\"u-margin-s-bottom u-h4\">Publication milestones</h3><p class=\"u-margin-m-bottom\">The dates displayed for an article provide information on when various publication milestones were reached at the journal that has published the article. Where applicable, activities on preceding journals at which the article was previously under consideration are not shown (for instance submission, revisions, rejection).</p><p class=\"u-margin-xs-bottom\">The publication milestones include:</p><ul class=\"key-dates-help-list u-margin-m-bottom u-padding-s-left\"><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Received</span>: The date the article was originally submitted to the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Revised</span>: The date the most recent revision of the article was submitted to the journal. Dates corresponding to intermediate revisions are not shown.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Accepted</span>: The date the article was accepted for publication in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Available online</span>: The date a version of the article was made available online in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Version of Record</span>: The date the finalized version of the article was made available in the journal.</li></ul><p>More information on publishing policies can be found on the <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/policies-and-standards/publishing-ethics\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing Ethics Policies</span></span></a> page. View our <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/researcher/author/submit-your-paper\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing with Elsevier: step-by-step</span></span></a> page to learn more about the publishing process. For any questions on your own submission or other questions related to publishing an article, <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://service.elsevier.com/app/phone/supporthub/publishing\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">contact our Researcher support team.</span></span></a></p></div>","title":"What do these dates mean?"}},"glossary":{},"issueNavigation":{"previous":{},"next":{}},"linkingHubLinks":{},"metrics":{"metricGroup":{"citations":[],"captures":[],"mentions":[],"socialMedia":[]},"isLoading":false,"error":false,"hasMetrics":false},"preview":{},"rawtext":"","recommendations":{},"references":{},"referenceLinks":{"internal":[],"internalLoaded":false,"external":[]},"refersTo":{},"referredToBy":{},"relatedContent":{"isModal":false,"isOpenSpecialIssueArticles":false,"isOpenVirtualSpecialIssueLink":false,"isOpenRecommendations":true,"isOpenSubstances":true,"citingArticles":[false,false,false,false,false,false],"recommendations":[false,false,false,false,false,false]},"seamlessAccess":{},"specialIssueArticles":{},"substances":{},"supplementaryFilesData":[],"tableOfContents":{"showEntitledTocLinks":true},"tail":{},"transientError":{"isOpen":false},"sidePanel":{"openState":1},"viewConfig":{"articleFeature":{"aiNavigation":true},"pathPrefix":""},"virtualSpecialIssue":{"showVirtualSpecialIssueLink":false},"usageProps":{"itemStage":"S300","isAip":false,"tombAip":"0","sample":false},"userCookiePreferences":{"STRICTLY_NECESSARY":true,"PERFORMANCE":true,"FUNCTIONAL":true,"TARGETING":false}};

70.2c.58-1.98.9-4.04.9-6.2s-.32-4.22-.9-6.2l28.42-15.28C77.56 47.1 83.44 50 90 50c12.14 0 22-9.86 22-22S102.14 6 90 6s-22 9.86-22 22c0 1.98.28 3.9.78 5.72L40.14 49.1C36.12 44.76 30.38 42 24 42 11.86 42 2 51.86 2 64s9.86 22 22 22c6.38 0 12.12-2.76 16.14-7.12l28.64 15.38c-.5 1.84-.78 3.76-.78 5.74 0 12.14 9.86 22 22 22s22-9.86 22-22-9.86-22-22-22z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Share</span></span></button></div></div></div><div class="ExportCitation u-display-inline-block" id="export-citation"><div class="popover export-citation-popover" id="export-citation-popover"><div id="popover-trigger-export-citation-popover"><button class="button-link button-link-secondary button-link-icon-left button-link-has-colored-icon" type="button" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="true"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 104 128" height="20" class="icon icon-cited-by-66"><path d="M2 58.78V106h44V64H12v-5.22C12 40.28 29.08 32 46 32V22C20.1 22 2 37.12 2 58.78zM102 32V22c-25.9 0-44 15.12-44 36.78V106h44V64H68v-5.22C68 40.28 85.08 32 102 32z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Cite</span></span></button></div></div></div></div></div><div class="ArticleIdentifierLinks u-margin-xs-bottom text-xs" id="article-identifier-links"><a class="anchor doi anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jpowsour.2024.234730" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" aria-label="Persistent link using digital object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jpowsour.2024.234730</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor rights-and-content anchor-primary" href="https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=ELS&amp;contentID=S0378775324006827&amp;orderBeanReset=true" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Get rights and content</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="LicenseInfo text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom"><div class="License"><span>Under a Creative Commons </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">license</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Open access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="abs0020" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="abssec0020"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0030"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">Hard carbons are the most extended anode materials for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs); however, they show some limitations.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">A simple, fast, low-cost treatment with small molecules blocks micropores, improves Na diffusion and increases capacity.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020"><em>Ex</em><em>-</em><em>situ</em><span> XPS demonstrates that thiol functional groups promote the formation of a favorable <a href="/topics/materials-science/solid-electrolyte" title="Learn more about solid electrolyte from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid electrolyte</a> interface.</span></div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0025">The treatment improves performance of soft carbons as well, demonstrating the wide applicability of the method.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="abs0010" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="abssec0010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010"><span>Hard carbons are the most extended <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode materials</a><span> for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs); however, they suffer from several limitations such as low stability, poor rate performance and low initial Coulombic efficiency (iCE). Herein, a simple, fast, and low-cost surface treatment at <a href="/topics/chemistry/ambient-reaction-temperature" title="Learn more about room temperature from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">room temperature</a> using short-chain organic molecules: 3-mercaptopropionic acid (MPA), 1,2-ethanedithiol (EDT) and </span></span><a href="/topics/chemistry/oxalic-acid" title="Learn more about oxalic acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxalic acid</a> (OxA) has been applied to a hard carbon (C1400).</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0015"><span>The carbons treated with sulfur containing molecules (MPA or EDT) exhibit higher capacity (12&nbsp;% capacity enhancement after 100th cycles at C/10 and 18&nbsp;% enhancement at 1C vs. C1400). The introduction of these ligands leads to improved micropore blockage, helping in the reversible insertion of <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about Na ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Na ions</a>. Moreover, </span><em>ex-situ</em><span> X-ray <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about photoelectron spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">photoelectron spectroscopy</a> (XPS) analyses demonstrate that thiol functional groups promote the formation of favorable NaF and Na</span><sub>2</sub><span>O-rich <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/solid-electrolyte" title="Learn more about solid electrolyte from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid electrolyte</a><span> interfaces (SEI) leading to and faster <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> diffusion in the plateau region. Additionally, MPA and EDT treatments have been applied to a soft carbon (Vulcan XC-72R) resulting in a substantial 30&nbsp;% capacity improvement after 100 cycles at 1C.</span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0020">These results demonstrate the wide applicability of the method as a straightforward and efficient strategy for improving the <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical properties</a> of carbon anodes used in SIBs.</div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="abs0015"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="abssec0015"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0025"><span>This study introduces an efficient and simple surface treatment with short chain ligands that blocks micropores, improves <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> diffusion, and increases capacity of carbons used as anodes in sodium-ion batteries. Ligands with thiol functional groups promote a NaF and Na</span><sub>2</sub>O-rich SEI, leading to anodes with improved capacity and stability.<span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="undfig1"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324006827-ga1.jpg" height="245" alt="Image 1"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324006827-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (360KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (360KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324006827-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775324006207"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775324006268"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="sec1"><h2 id="sectitle0030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035"><span>The pursuit of clean energy generation and efficient energy storage systems has become imperative in our society. As the global demand for energy continues to rise, there is a growing need to transition from fossil fuel-based power sources to cleaner alternatives. Therefore, <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/renewable-energy-source" title="Learn more about renewable energy sources from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">renewable energy sources</a><span> integration has become the focus of many countries and organizations as they have the potential to reduce greenhouse emissions and <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/fossil-fuel" title="Learn more about fossil fuel from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">fossil fuel</a><span> dependency. However, one of the primary challenges of <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/renewable-energy" title="Learn more about renewable energy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">renewable energy</a> lies in its storage capabilities. Unlike fossil fuels, that can provide instant energy when required, renewable sources are reliant on climate conditions, resulting in occasional energy peaks and fluctuations in energy generation, including both oversupplies and undersupplies [</span></span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib1" name="bbib1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a><span><span>]. To address these challenges the development of efficient energy storage systems has become critical. Nowadays lithium-ion <a href="/topics/chemistry/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about batteries from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">batteries</a> (LIBs) are the most used systems in portable electronics and are considered a highly important storage system for short and intermittent energy storage due to their high </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> and design flexibility. Nevertheless, despite their widespread use, they have well-known drawbacks. These limitations include scarcity and limited geographic distribution of key materials like lithium or cobalt, safety issues, and the formation of dendrites [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib2" name="bbib2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib3" name="bbib3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib4" name="bbib4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a><span>]. In recent years sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) gain a significant interest due to the abundance of <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a><span><span>, the potential cost-effectiveness, and environmental acceptance. However, one of the major challenges is the development of an <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode material</a> able to effectively store </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ions</a><span>. While graphite is commonly used as the anode material in standard rechargeable LIBs, it is inadequate for SIBs, due to its inability to form binary compounds with <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> ions [</span></span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib5" name="bbib5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">5</span></span></a><span>]. As a result, the identification and development of alternative anode materials for SIBs has become a priority in the field of <a href="/topics/chemistry/electrochemical-energy-storage" title="Learn more about electrochemical storage from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical storage</a> research.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040"><span>In this context, <a href="/topics/materials-science/amorphous-carbon" title="Learn more about amorphous carbons from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">amorphous carbons</a> such as hard carbons (HCs) and soft carbons (SCs), have risen as the most common option for anodes in SIBs. Their low-cost, and environmentally friendly synthesis combined with great storage capacity have placed them in the spotlight in recent years. HCs are currently the preferred anode in commercial SIBs (for example, CATL, Tiamat, and Faradion batteries); however, SIBs using SCs anode are also being commercialized (HiNA Battery) [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib6" name="bbib6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">6</span></span></a><span>]. HCs are mainly obtained from the <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/carbonization" title="Learn more about carbonization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbonization</a> of biomass-based precursors. They exhibit great capacity values that can reach 300&nbsp;mAh·g</span><sup>−1</sup>, mainly due to their low-potential plateau below 0.1&nbsp;V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib7" name="bbib7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib8" name="bbib8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib9" name="bbib9" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib9"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib10" name="bbib10" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib10"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>]. However, this also results in poor rate performance and low stability [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib11" name="bbib11" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib11"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">11</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib12" name="bbib12" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib12"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">12</span></span></a><span>]. In contrast to HCs, SCs are obtained from high-temperature <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/pyrolysis" title="Learn more about pyrolysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pyrolysis</a><span> of <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/aromatic-compound" title="Learn more about aromatic compounds from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">aromatic compounds</a>. They exhibit a sloping region during both the sodiation and desodiation processes, lacking a low-potential plateau, which results in enhanced stability and better high-rate performance. However, their average capacities tend to be lower than those of hard carbons oscillating between 100 and 250&nbsp;mAh·g</span></span><sup>−1</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib9" name="bbib9" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib9"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">9</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib11" name="bbib11" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib11"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">11</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib12" name="bbib12" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib12"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">12</span></span></a>]. The differences in their sodium storage mechanisms arise from their nanometric structure, where SCs exhibit less curvature and a higher degree of order in the stacking of their graphene layers [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib12" name="bbib12" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib12"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">12</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045"><span><span><span>One of the most important concepts in the anode performance is the <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/solid-electrolyte" title="Learn more about solid electrolyte from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid electrolyte</a> interphase (SEI) which is crucial for the </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/electrochemistry" title="Learn more about electrochemistry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemistry</a> of </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about sodium ion batteries from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ion batteries</a> (SIBs) anodes due to its influence on sodium transport and stability. The term SEI was first introduced in 1979 by </span><em>Peled</em><span> when he observed a layer formation on <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/alkali-metal" title="Learn more about alkali metal from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">alkali metal</a> upon contact with organic electrolytes [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>]. This layer was found to be ionically conductive but nonconductive electronically. In 1997, <em>Peled</em> et al. proposed the “mosaic model” as the prevailing structure, which continues to be widely accepted in present times [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib14" name="bbib14" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib14"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">14</span></span></a>]. This structure comprises small domains of inorganic, organic salts and polymers which allow the transfer of the ions (Li, Na, K …) and protects the surface of the anode [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib15" name="bbib15" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib15"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a><span>]. These species are formed upon decomposition of the organic electrolyte on the anode surface during the first cycle. This process is influenced by the nature of the <a href="/topics/materials-science/organic-solvents" title="Learn more about organic solvents from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">organic solvents</a>, electrolyte salt, additives, and functional groups on the anode surface [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib15" name="bbib15" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib15"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib16" name="bbib16" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib16"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">16</span></span></a>]. Unfortunately, hard carbons and soft carbons usually form inhomogeneous SEI layers with commercial electrolytes which lead to low initial Coulombic efficiency (iCE), low cycling stability, and poor rate capability [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib17" name="bbib17" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib17"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">17</span></span></a><span>]. SEI engineering and interface <a href="/topics/chemistry/chemistry" title="Learn more about chemistry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">chemistry</a> regulation have risen as possible solutions to improve the LIBs and SIBs performance [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib18" name="bbib18" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib18"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib19" name="bbib19" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib19"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">19</span></span></a>]. Different approaches have been proposed to tune the SEI such as: different electrolyte solvents [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib20" name="bbib20" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib20"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib21" name="bbib21" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib21"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a><span>], <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrolyte-additive" title="Learn more about electrolyte additives from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrolyte additives</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib16" name="bbib16" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib16"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">16</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib22" name="bbib22" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib22"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22</span></span></a><span>], <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/oxygen-plasma" title="Learn more about oxygen plasma from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxygen plasma</a> functionalization [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib23" name="bbib23" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib23"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">23</span></span></a><span>], and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/atomic-layer-epitaxy" title="Learn more about atomic layer deposition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">atomic layer deposition</a> (ALD) [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib24" name="bbib24" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib24"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">24</span></span></a><span>]. Another common approach is the coating of HC anodes with SC or preparing HC-SC composites to block open pores, reduce <a href="/topics/chemistry/surface-area" title="Learn more about surface area from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface area</a> and therefore, decrease the SEI decomposition to enhance the iCE [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib25" name="bbib25" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib25"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">25</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib26" name="bbib26" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib26"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a><span>]. Special attention has been placed on introducing oxygen functional groups on the surface of the carbon anode via chemical <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxidation-reaction" title="Learn more about oxidation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxidation</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib27" name="bbib27" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib27"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>] or <em>in-situ</em><span> polymerization of carbonyl-rich molecules to improve <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/wettability" title="Learn more about wettability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">wettability</a> and act as active sites for electrolyte decomposition [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib17" name="bbib17" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib17"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">17</span></span></a>]. Additionally, carbon functionalization using molecules has also been explored. <em>Romero-Cano</em> et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib28" name="bbib28" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib28"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">28</span></span></a>] proposed the incorporation of N-rich molecules (urea and melamine) to homogenize the surface chemistry of hard carbons, preventing irreversibility and providing extra capacity storage mechanisms. <em>Yu</em> et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib29" name="bbib29" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib29"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a><span>] modified the surface of an HC using 2,2-dimethylvinyl <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/boric-acid" title="Learn more about boric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">boric acid</a><span> (DEBA) to construct a more stable SEI achieving an iCE of 77&nbsp;% and 90&nbsp;% capacity retention after 2000 cycles in comparison to the 65&nbsp;% iCE and 54&nbsp;% capacity retention of unmodified hard carbon. These surface treatments have shown to improve the capacity, stability, and iCE of pristine carbons; however, most of them require complex techniques, high temperatures, long treatment times, or modifying the synthesis and <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/pyrolysis" title="Learn more about pyrolysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pyrolysis</a> steps of the carbon.</span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050"><span><span>Two of the most used solvents in SIBs are ethylene carbonate (EC) and <a href="/topics/chemistry/dimethyl-carbonate" title="Learn more about dimethyl carbonate from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">dimethyl carbonate</a> (DMC) due to their high </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/dielectric-constant" title="Learn more about dielectric constant from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">dielectric constant</a><span>, low viscosity, and high <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/ionic-mobility" title="Learn more about ionic mobility from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ionic mobility</a>. They undergo decomposition upon contact with the anode during the initial sodiation and desodiation cycles mainly forming Na</span></span><sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>, Na<sub>2</sub><span>O and several <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/polycarbonate" title="Learn more about polycarbonates from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polycarbonates</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib20" name="bbib20" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib20"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a>]. Additionally, additives such as fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) and the NaPF<sub>6</sub> salt decompose to form NaF [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib16" name="bbib16" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib16"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">16</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib30" name="bbib30" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib30"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">30</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib31" name="bbib31" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib31"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">31</span></span></a>]. It has been reported that a high amount of carbonates in the SEI is detrimental to SIB performance [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib32" name="bbib32" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib32"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">32</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib33" name="bbib33" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib33"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">33</span></span></a>]. On the other hand, other inorganic components of SEI such as Na<sub>2</sub>O and NaF possess higher Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;conductivity and migration than organic compounds, which induces better rate capability [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib17" name="bbib17" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib17"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">17</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib32" name="bbib32" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib32"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">32</span></span></a><span>], provides high <a href="/topics/materials-science/mechanical-strength" title="Learn more about mechanical strength from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mechanical strength</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib34" name="bbib34" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib34"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">34</span></span></a>], and suppresses the growth of Na dendrites leading to better stability [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib35" name="bbib35" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib35"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib36" name="bbib36" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib36"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib37" name="bbib37" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib37"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055"><span><span><span>In this work we propose a simple, fast, and low-cost surface treatment at <a href="/topics/chemistry/ambient-reaction-temperature" title="Learn more about room temperature from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">room temperature</a> using short-chain organic molecules: 3-mercaptopropionic acid (MPA), 1,2-ethanedithiol (EDT) and </span><a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/oxalic-acid" title="Learn more about oxalic acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxalic acid</a><span> (OxA). They are short-chain ligands of similar size containing functional groups such as thiols (MPA and EDT) and <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/carboxylic-acid" title="Learn more about carboxylic acids from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carboxylic acids</a> (MPA and OxA), which can enhance the interaction between the electrode surface and electrolyte, and modify the </span></span><a href="/topics/chemistry/phase-composition" title="Learn more about composition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">composition</a> of the SEI [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib38" name="bbib38" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib38"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">38</span></span></a><span><span>]. In a previous study, we observed a notable enhancement in the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/wettability" title="Learn more about wettability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">wettability</a>, capacity, and stability of an aqueous </span><a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/electrochemical-capacitor" title="Learn more about supercapacitor from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">supercapacitor</a> electrode upon the introduction of the short-chain organic molecule MPA [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib39" name="bbib39" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib39"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">39</span></span></a>]. However, a deeper study on the reasons behind these improvements was not performed. In this study, we have studied the effect of having different functional groups on SEI formation, with special emphasis on the formation of carbonates (CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2−</sup>), Na<sub>2</sub><span>O and NaF contents and their influence on <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemistry" title="Learn more about electrochemistry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemistry</a>. A corncob-derived carbon (C1400) has been chosen as a hard carbon (HC) model. This hard carbon has proven to be very promising for Na-ion battery anodes, but it exhibited problems with ion blockage related to SEI formation [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib40" name="bbib40" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib40"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">40</span></span></a>]. Given the positive impact of the surface treatments on the hard carbon performance, the best performing treatments have been applied to Vulcan XC-72R (chosen as the soft carbon model), showing a more noticeable capacity improvement. These results demonstrate the versatility and wide applicability of the method for both HCs and SCs.</div></section><section id="sec2"><h2 id="sectitle0035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental (materials and methods)</h2><section id="sec2.1"><h3 id="sectitle0040" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Materials</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0060"><span><span>Organic ligands 3-mercaptopropionic acid (MPA), 1,2-ethanedithiol (EDT), and <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/oxalic-acid" title="Learn more about oxalic acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxalic acid</a> (OxA) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Toluene (&gt;98&nbsp;%), and </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/purity" title="Learn more about pure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pure</a><span> <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/acetonitrile" title="Learn more about acetonitrile from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">acetonitrile</a> were purchased from VWR Chemicals. H</span></span><sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> (&gt;98&nbsp;%) was acquired from ACRO Organics.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0065"><span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/vinylidene" title="Learn more about Polyvinylidene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Polyvinylidene</a> fluoride (PVDF) (M</span><sub>w</sub><span> ∼ 534,000 (GPC)), <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a><span> chunks, ethylene carbonate (EC), and <a href="/topics/chemistry/dimethyl-carbonate" title="Learn more about dimethyl carbonate from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">dimethyl carbonate</a> (DMC) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Sodium hexafluorophosphate (NaPF</span></span><sub>6</sub><span>), and fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) were purchased from Alfa Aesar. Super C65 conductive carbon was purchased from Imerys, N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) was obtained from Merck, Carbon-coated <a href="/topics/materials-science/aluminum-foil" title="Learn more about aluminum foil from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">aluminum foil</a> was acquired from Armor, France, and Vulcan XC-72R was kindly provided by CABOT corporation.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0070"><span>Corncob was obtained from a local field. Preceding the <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/pyrolysis" title="Learn more about pyrolysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pyrolysis</a> process, the corncob underwent an overnight drying procedure in a dryer maintained at 80&nbsp;°C. The initial heat treatment was performed within a quartz tube furnace, exposed to a flow of argon (15&nbsp;L&nbsp;h</span><sup>−1</sup>), during which the temperature was elevated to 900&nbsp;°C at a rate of 2.5&nbsp;°C·min<sup>−1</sup><span>. Upon reaching 900&nbsp;°C, the temperature was sustained for a duration of 1&nbsp;h before gradual cooling to <a href="/topics/chemistry/ambient-reaction-temperature" title="Learn more about room temperature from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">room temperature</a>. Subsequently, the second phase entailed elevating temperature to 1400&nbsp;°C using an Al</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> tube furnace, while maintaining an argon flow (50&nbsp;L&nbsp;h<sup>−1</sup>). The heating rate was fixed at 2.5&nbsp;°C·min<sup>−1</sup>, and the temperature was held constant for 1&nbsp;h, followed by cooling to room temperature. After the pyrolysis, the obtained corncob C1400 hard carbon was grinded [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib40" name="bbib40" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib40"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">40</span></span></a>].</div></section><section id="sec2.2"><h3 id="sectitle0045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Surface treatments</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0075"><span>Organic ligand solutions (MPA 1&nbsp;M, EDT 1&nbsp;M, and OxA 0.1&nbsp;M) were prepared by dissolving MPA, EDT, or OxA in <a href="/topics/chemistry/acetonitrile" title="Learn more about acetonitrile from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">acetonitrile</a><span> or in an acidic <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/acetonitrile" title="Learn more about acetonitrile from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">acetonitrile</a> solution (0.1&nbsp;M H</span></span><sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub><span><span> in acetonitrile). Two sets of surface-treated samples were prepared with <a href="/topics/chemistry/sulfuric-acid" title="Learn more about sulfuric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sulfuric acid</a> (CA-L) and without (C-L) to analyze the effect of including the acid. Corncob 1400&nbsp;°C powder was thoroughly mixed with freshly prepared organic ligand solutions (1&nbsp;mL of solution per 100&nbsp;mg of carbon) for 30&nbsp;min under vigorous stirring. Afterward, samples were washed several times with acetonitrile and toluene and dried at 80&nbsp;°C overnight. Samples were labeled as C1400 for the original hard </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/carbon-material" title="Learn more about carbon material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon material</a>, and C-MPA, C-EDT, and C-OxA for the surface treated samples without H</span><sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub><span>. On the other hand, C1400 carbon treated with <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/sulphuric-acid" title="Learn more about sulfuric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sulfuric acid</a> was labeled as CA, CA-MPA, CA-EDT, and CA-OxA when H</span><sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> was included in the ligand solution.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0080">In the case of the soft carbon (Vulcan XC-72R) treatments, the treatment was slightly modified due to the higher porosity of the soft carbon. We added 2&nbsp;mL of 0.5&nbsp;M MPA or EDT solutions in acetonitrile per 100&nbsp;mg of carbon. Samples were labeled as V-MPA or V-EDT.</div></section><section id="sec2.3"><h3 id="sectitle0050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Electrode preparation and cell assembly</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085"><span><span>Electrode slurries were prepared with a <a href="/topics/chemistry/phase-composition" title="Learn more about composition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">composition</a> of 90 %wt. of active material (C1400, C-L, CA-L, Vulcan or V-L), 5 %wt. of PVDF binder, and a 5 %wt. of conductive carbon C65. NMP was used as a solvent. The mixture was ball milled at 300&nbsp;rpm for 30&nbsp;min to obtain a homogeneous slurry. The slurry was coated on Al/C foil using a doctor blade applicator resulting in a uniform coating with a thickness of 100&nbsp;μm. The final coated material underwent an overnight drying process at 80&nbsp;°C. Subsequently, electrodes with a diameter of 15&nbsp;mm were cut and stored within an argon-filled </span><a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/gloveboxes" title="Learn more about glovebox from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">glovebox</a>, featuring mass loadings ranging between 1.5 and 2&nbsp;mg&nbsp;cm</span><sup>−2</sup>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0090"><span><span>Two-electrode CR2032 type coin cells were assembled in an argon-filled <a href="/topics/chemistry/glovebox-technique" title="Learn more about glovebox from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">glovebox</a> with water and oxygen contents below 0.5&nbsp;ppm. C1400, Vulcan, surface-treated C1400 or surface-treated Vulcan materials were used as </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/working-electrode" title="Learn more about working electrodes from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">working electrodes</a><span> while <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a><span> metal was used as the counter/reference electrode. Both electrodes were separated by a <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/fibreglass" title="Learn more about glass fiber from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">glass fiber</a> separator. The electrolyte used was 1&nbsp;M NaPF</span></span></span><sub>6</sub><span> dissolved in EC:DMC (1:1 %vol.) with 2 %wt. FEC additive. Each cell was carefully loaded with 100&nbsp;μL of the <a href="/topics/chemistry/electrolyte" title="Learn more about electrolyte solution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrolyte solution</a>.</span></div></section><section id="sec2.4"><h3 id="sectitle0055" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.4. Physical characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0095">N<sub>2</sub><span><span> adsorption measurements were performed using ASAP 2020 gas <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/sorption" title="Learn more about sorption from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sorption</a> analyzer from Micromeritics. The </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/degasification" title="Learn more about degassing from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">degassing</a><span> step was performed at 120&nbsp;°C. MicroActive software was used to process the data and obtain the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) <a href="/topics/chemistry/surface-area" title="Learn more about surface area from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface area</a><span> by using Rouquerol procedure. Carbon slit pores by NLDFT model was used for the <a href="/topics/chemistry/pore-size-distribution" title="Learn more about pore size distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pore size distribution</a> calculations.</span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0100"><span><span>Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images and Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) analysis were performed in a SEM Inspect 50 instrument. <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about Transmission electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Transmission electron microscopy</a> (TEM) images were acquired using a Tecnai F30 microscope operating at 300&nbsp;kV. Samples were prepared by sonicating carbon powders in ethanol and adding a couple of drops on holey-carbon copper grids. </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/thermogravimetric-analysis" title="Learn more about Thermogravimetric analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Thermogravimetric analysis</a> (TGA) was performed under 50&nbsp;mL&nbsp;min</span><sup>−1</sup> N<sub>2</sub> flow, from 35&nbsp;°C to 1000&nbsp;°C at a heating rate of 10&nbsp;°C·min<sup>−1</sup><span> on a TGA Q5000 IR from TA Instruments. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed in an X-ray <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffractometers" title="Learn more about diffractometer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffractometer</a><span> PANalytical Empyrean instrument in Bragg-Brentano configuration using Cu Kα radiation and equipped with a PIXcel1D detector. <a href="/topics/chemistry/attenuated-total-reflection" title="Learn more about Attenuated total reflection from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Attenuated total reflection</a> Fourier transform infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectra were obtained using a Bruker Vertex-70 FTIR spectrophotometer with a Golden Gate diamond ATR module. Data points were collected from 3500&nbsp;cm</span></span><sup>−1</sup> to 1000&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup>&nbsp;at a resolution of 4&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup><span> and 512 number of scans. X-ray <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about photoelectron spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">photoelectron spectroscopy</a> (XPS) of carbon materials was performed with an Axis Supra spectrometer (Kratos Tech). </span><em>Ex-situ</em> X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of cycled electrodes was performed using the Versa probe 3 AD (Physical Electronics, Chanhassen, U.S.A) with a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source operating at 15&nbsp;kV and 13.3&nbsp;mA. Samples were subjected to cycling at a C/10 rate, comprising one discharge and one charge cycle. Subsequently, the half-cell was disassembled, and the HC electrode was meticulously cleaned using DMC prior to the analysis. Cycled electrodes were put on a non-conductive double-sided scotch tape in the “floating” setup and placed in the center of the XPS holder inside an argon filled glove box. The samples were transferred inside into the XPS intro chamber with a transfer vessel without air exposure. For each sample, spectra were acquired by scanning a 1&nbsp;×&nbsp;1 mm<sup>2</sup><span><span> area with the spot size of 200&nbsp;μm. Narrow spectra were acquired at a pass energy of 27&nbsp;eV and step of 0.05&nbsp;eV to obtain high <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/data-quality" title="Learn more about quality data from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">quality data</a>. Analysis of the peaks was performed with the CasaXPS software using a weighted sum of Lorentzian and </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/gaussian-distribution" title="Learn more about Gaussian from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Gaussian</a> component curves after Shirley background subtraction. The binding energies were referenced to the internal C1s standard at 284.6&nbsp;eV.</span></div></section><section id="sec2.5"><h3 id="sectitle0060" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.5. Electrochemical characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0105">The electrochemical characterization was performed by using Maccor Series 4200 or GAMRY equipment. Measurements consisted of charge–discharge C/10 galvanostatic cycling (100 cycles at 0.03&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>) or modified galvanostatic cycling (first 5 cycles at C/10 followed by 100 cycles at 1C or 0.3&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>). Cycling was performed in the voltage range between 2&nbsp;V and 5&nbsp;mV. Voltage hold was applied at the lower cut-off for 5&nbsp;h or until the current dropped to C/100. The theoretical capacity was chosen following the model proposed by <em>Bommier</em> et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib41" name="bbib41" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib41"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">41</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110"><span><span>Modified Galvanostatic Intermittent <a href="/topics/chemistry/titration" title="Learn more about Titration from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Titration</a> Technique (GITT) measurements were performed at C/10 applied current during 30&nbsp;min with 2&nbsp;h of relaxation between steps. Apparent </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficients from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficients</a> were calculated from Fick's second law and linear correlation assumptions [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib42" name="bbib42" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib42"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">42</span></span></a>]. C-rate performance measurements were conducted within a voltage window from 2&nbsp;V to 0.005&nbsp;V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup><span><span><span>. The protocol included an initial stabilization cycle to form the <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/solid-electrolyte" title="Learn more about SEI from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SEI</a> and 5 consecutive cycles with the current 30&nbsp;mAh g-1 (C/10) with applied constant voltage at the lower cut-off until the current drops below C/100 or during a maximum of 5&nbsp;h. Subsequently, 5 cycles at each respective current were performed. The time limits of the voltage hold were accordingly adjusted to the different C-rates (2.5&nbsp;h for C/5, 1&nbsp;h for C/2 …). </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy</a> (EIS) were performed using a 2-electrode half-cell experimental configuration, using an amplitude of 10&nbsp;mV across a frequency range from 100&nbsp;kHz to 0.01&nbsp;Hz. Circuit modeling and </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/data-transmission" title="Learn more about data processing from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">data processing</a> was performed using the GAMRY Echem Analyst software.</span></div></section></section><section id="sec3"><h2 id="sectitle0065" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><section id="sec3.1"><h3 id="sectitle0070" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1. Physico-chemical characterization of surface-treated materials</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0115"><span>Surface-treated materials were prepared by simply mixing the carbon powder with the ligand solution under constant stirring at room temperature for 30&nbsp;min. At the beginning, <a href="/topics/chemistry/sulfuric-acid" title="Learn more about sulfuric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sulfuric acid</a><span><span> was used for the preparation of the ligand solutions to enhance the bonding between ligands and hard carbon due to its catalytic properties, especially in reactions such as <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/carboxylic-acid" title="Learn more about carboxylic acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carboxylic acid</a> </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/esterification" title="Learn more about esterification from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">esterification</a> (Fisher esterification) [</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib43" name="bbib43" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib43"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">43</span></span></a>]. But, it was observed that ligands were present on the surface even without acid treatment.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0120"><span><a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD patterns</a> show that surface treatments do not modify the C1400 crystalline structure (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>a and b). The expected (002) and (100) carbon peaks are distinguished in all materials [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib40" name="bbib40" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib40"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">40</span></span></a><span><span>]. With regards to <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/sulphuric-acid" title="Learn more about sulfuric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sulfuric acid</a> pretreated samples, the emergence of new peaks was observed, which may be indicative of the formation of </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/sulfate-salt" title="Learn more about sulfate salts from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sulfate salts</a> (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>a). This hypothesis was further supported by the disappearance of the peaks after washing the samples with water (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>). Moreover, C-OxA and CA-OxA show two common peaks at 26° and 30° which might correspond to solid oxalic acid [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib44" name="bbib44" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib44"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">44</span></span></a>]. All samples treated with carboxylic-ending molecules (OxA and MPA) show a new signal at 1680&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> in the ATR-FTIR spectra (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>), that is attributed to the C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond"><span>O <a href="/topics/chemistry/stretching-vibration" title="Learn more about stretching vibration from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">stretching vibration</a> of the carboxylic groups. The sample C-OxA shows the signal at 1705&nbsp;cm</span><sup>−1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>b) which corresponds to the second harmonic stretching of the same bond [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib45" name="bbib45" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib45"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">45</span></span></a>]. As expected, C1400, CA, CA-EDT or C-EDT samples show no signal at this wavenumber. No S–H stretching signal between 2600 and 2500&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup><span><span> has been found for any of the samples probably due to the interaction of sulfur with carbon or <a href="/topics/chemistry/deprotonation" title="Learn more about deprotonation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">deprotonation</a> of the </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/thiol-group" title="Learn more about thiol group from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">thiol group</a>.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig1"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324006827-gr1.jpg" height="453" alt="Fig. 1" aria-describedby="cap0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324006827-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (616KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (616KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324006827-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0010"><p id="fspara0010"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. <span><a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD patterns</a> of C1400, (a) CA-L samples and (b) C-L samples. TGA curves of the (c) CA-L and (d) C-L; both under N</span><sub>2</sub> atmosphere.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0125"><span><a href="/topics/chemistry/thermogravimetric-analysis" title="Learn more about TGA from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TGA</a><span><span> measurements have been performed to quantify and confirm the incorporation of the organic ligands on the <a href="/topics/materials-science/carbon-surface" title="Learn more about carbon surface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon surface</a>. Experiments were conducted in a nitrogen atmosphere to identify organic molecules adhered to the carbon surface and to differentiate variations in the </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/mechanical-strength" title="Learn more about strength from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">strength</a> of chemical bonding as a function of degradation temperature. Mass losses before 150&nbsp;°C are attributed to adsorbed solvents and water [</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib46" name="bbib46" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib46"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">46</span></span></a>]. Samples treated in acidic media are compared with sulfuric acid-treated carbon (CA) in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>c, and the surface treated samples are compared with the native carbon (C1400) in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>d. Mass losses in CA are attributed to the decomposition of surface functional groups and degradation of C–SO<sub>x</sub> generated by interaction with the acid (240 °C–350&nbsp;°C) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib47" name="bbib47" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib47"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">47</span></span></a>]. As expected, additional degradations are observed at 190&nbsp;°C for CA-OxA, 230&nbsp;°C for CA-EDT, and 200–235&nbsp;°C for CA-MPA, attributed to molecules chemically bonded to the carbon through C–O and C–S bonds [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib46" name="bbib46" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib46"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib47" name="bbib47" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib47"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib48" name="bbib48" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib48"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib49" name="bbib49" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib49"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>]. The difference in degradation temperature suggests that MPA and EDT are more strongly bound to the carbon than OxA. Moreover, CA-MPA and CA-EDT samples show an additional mass loss at 350&nbsp;°C, which can indicate C–S interaction between thiols and carbon surface, or aliphatic carbons bonded to oxygen (C<sub>al</sub>–O) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib47" name="bbib47" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib47"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">47</span></span></a>]. Non pretreated carbon (C1400, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>d) shows two mass losses at 330&nbsp;°C and 450&nbsp;°C due to the decomposition of functional surface groups. Besides, surface-treated materials show their first degradation at 205&nbsp;°C for C-OxA, 250&nbsp;°C for C-EDT and 282&nbsp;°C for C-MPA with a shoulder at 230&nbsp;°C. Again, MPA and EDT appear to be more strongly bonded to carbon than OxA. These results evidence the successful functionalization of the carbon with the three ligand molecules regardless of the presence of sulfuric acid in the treatment. Furthermore, loadings of the different ligands have been compiled in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl1" name="btbl1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 1</span></span></a>. MPA and EDT loading is around 0.5 %wt. and 0.2 %wt. for OxA. The utilization of sulfuric acid seems to have a negligible impact on the quantity of incorporated ligands.</div><div class="tables frame-topbot colsep-0 rowsep-0" id="tbl1"><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0040"><p id="tspara0010"><span class="label">Table 1</span>. TGA quantification of surface treated samples. Mass losses within the range of chemical bonding (150 °C–300&nbsp;°C), C–S bonds or C<sub>al</sub>–O (300 °C–400&nbsp;°C) and stronger interactions (400 °C–600&nbsp;°C) have been considered. Quantification of ligands was calculated from the difference between the total mass loss of the treated material and their respective reference material, C1400 or CA.</p></span></span><div (%wt.)</em></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">CA</td><td class="align-center">0.5</td><td class="align-center">0.5</td><td class="align-center">0.7</td><td class="align-center">0.4</td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><td class="align-left">CA-EDT</td><td class="align-center">0.8</td><td class="align-center">0.6</td><td class="align-center">0.9</td><td
